1.subquestion: By what percentage will the initial price increase over these three years combined?

subanswer.text: In one year, prices rise by 5%, or multiply by 1.05 times their current value; therefore, they grow exponentially based on compounding interest formula P(t)=P₀e^(rt), where r=rate of growth per period, t=number of periods, P(t) is final value, e≈2.71828 (the base of natural logarithms). Here, since our rate changes annually rather than continuously, let’s use discrete multiplication instead i.e., multiplying the previous value by an annualized factor raised to power equal number of years passed. Thus, Final Price F=(Initial Price I)(Growth Rate g)^Year Number Y=[I*g^Y] here assuming Yearly Compounding [(Final Value)/(Original Cost)]=(1+r)^T . Plugging values from problem statement results in [F/(I)*((1+g)^Y]=([$1604814]/[$1604814])*(1.05^3)=[($1604814)/($1604814)]*[(~1.1576)..i.e approximately equals ~1.1576]. Hence Carrot Prices Will Be ($1604814)*(~1.1576)=~$1857320 when rounded off nearest Integer Approximation.[Because Total Percentage Change Over All Period Together Is Just Like Accumulated Annual Percentage Changes Multiplied](https://www.calculator.net/compound-interest-calculator.html): Using calculator returns same result above.) Answer 5.1 is approximately 15.76%.
